job_title: Teacher in New York, NY
pros: It’s rewarding and inspiring to mentor the next generation of visual artists.
cons: The pay is not great, but I had a lot of autonomy.

job_title: Associate Director in New York, NY
pros: At one point, a really long time ago, under the original founder's leadership, you could sometimes build cool programs, things, etc.
cons: Worst executive leadership team I've ever experienced in my life. The three leaders at the top all have completely different visions for how the school should be run. It's a toxic environment, particularly for women and minorities (unless you're like the 1-2 people who are grandfathered into the family). In short - run for the hills if you aren't a white, Jewish male. And honestly, even if you are, you should still probably run. This place is an absolute toxic dumpster fire .

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: sometimes it feels like there is not much direction but its a good starting point for a career in media
cons: lack of direction and not great pay

review_title: Great Place, Make the Most of your Time There
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great people. Ability to learn on the job. Amazing place to network and learn from others.
cons: Not much opportunity for growth. Stubborn leadership.

job_title: Department Chair in New York, NY
pros: The faculty here are second to none!
cons: No 401K match. Communication issues.

job_title: Teacher in New York, NY
pros: the high school students were bright and willing.
cons: the school was badly run. Some students were promised stardom but couldn't speak English, didn't disclose their ADD, could not memorize lines. Students were accepted if their check cleared.

job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The other instructors and students are wonderful.
cons: The management are incompetent and cruel to employees.

job_title: Professor in New York, NY
pros: Nice people, smart co-workers and lively students.
cons: Underpaid, higher-ups not supportive of staff, difficult to negotiate with.

job_title: Administrator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The students are wonderful and very diverse
cons:
They pay terribly, the management style is not loyal or constructive, and mostly men with large egos. It constantly felt like they were trying to spend as little money as possible no matter how that affected the students or the faculty. 

The president is very rude and it seems like most of the upper admin fear him and his unpredictable behavior. I was there for years and I saw almost every person of color in a leadership position quit. About 6 people in 3 years. It's hard to feel supported there and they are not looking at there relationship to marginalized communities at all therefore alienating people and they don't want to work there anymore. Every person I worked with complained about their job and how little they were paid and how inconsistent and confusing the messaging from upper admin was.

job_title: Teacher Assistant in New York, NY
pros: everything is great at NYFA
cons: working hours are very less in internship

review_title: Good position to work as a freelancer, but the wage isn't competitive with other film jobs
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Burbank, CA
pros:
-Flexible hours if you're a freelancer. Unlike other part-time jobs, they'll schedule hours based on availability. They don't hold it against you if you're working on a long shoot or project.
-Good place to network with other people who aspire to work in various areas of film production
-Good place to learn more without paying for film classes
-Co-workers are really friendly and supportive.
cons:
-If don't have any freelance opportunities, a 40-hour work week is not guaranteed
-Hourly wage doesn't provide a livable income in Los Angeles
-Certain shifts can be slow

review_title: The price of working with what you love
job_title: Prefer To Remain Anonymous in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Beautiful young creative people
- Might be something that you love to do, depending on your job there
- Kinda flexible for taking UNPAID time-off, if needed
cons:
- Micromanagement culture by top decision-makers
- Internal communication on a need-to-know basis from top to bottom
- Salaries on the lower side of the market range
- 5 days paid vacation after 1 year
- 3 days PT/Sick leave for non-exempt (each 2h)

job_title: HR Assistant in Burbank, CA
pros: Easy work, didn’t take my work home
cons: The culture was lacking for sure

job_title: Instructor in Burbank, CA
pros: Super mix of international students and getting an opportunity to work with people from all over the world was a tremendous amount of fun.
cons: Sometimes it was clear that students weren't the priority.

job_title: Registrar File Clerk in New York, NY
pros: Nothing positive to say. Don’t work here.
cons: Very toxic environment. The registrar’s office is not organized at all and expects new people to come in a fix the problem when it’s the head of company that needs to take the lead in organizing things and make their employees over worked and stressed.

review_title: Just don’t stay here too long
job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
Flexibility
The student body is mostly enjoyable to work with.
Cool colleagues (this is campus specific)
The chance to travel (this is not common)
Promotes from within (also campus specific)
Chances to teach in multiple departments 
If you do a good/decent job you can stay with NYFA quite sometime.
cons: There is a big difference in working at the New York and LA campus. The institution as a whole is not an ideal place to work. Also it’s important to bear in mind that NYFA has a bad reputation. The NY campus is a much better campus to work on than the LA campus. The LA campus is more spread out and it’s very easy to end up being isolated as a part-timer. Another major con is that it is not always clear how to improve at this school. By that I mean you may not know what you should do to improve your instruction or duties and you may have no clue how to move up a level. Being promoted is the luck of the draw at NYFA. Once you get the lay of the land it is possible to navigate it fairly well and to position yourself well. How to do it is not transparent. Lastly, the diversity of the teaching staff is awful particularly on the LA campus. You may find it tough teaching here as someone who is BIPOC and or a female as the pay in the past has been discriminatory and they will certainly hold you to a higher standard  then your white male colleagues. There is a good old boys club at NYFA. This will not not necessarily hamper you from being hired, but it can become problematic in other ways.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Next door to Warner Bros studio lot. International student body.
cons: No cost of living raises. Students taking too many classes per semester.

job_title: Instructor in London, England
pros:
*Flexible Schedule
*Opportunity to create own curriculum 
*Diverse Students
cons:
*Faculty is underpaid
*No raise in over 4 years of working there
*For profit school

job_title: Registrar Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Friendly coworkers. Good environment to work in.
cons: No promotional opportunities. Pay is constant. No good benefits.

job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Nice interesting students and colleagues
cons: Management does not recognize loyal employees

review_title: Micro Managers that Don’t Give Support
job_title: Instructor in New York, NY
pros: The pay is adequate and the flexible schedule is nice
cons: Signing an NDA that states you can’t disparage them for 10 years is very very suspect. There’s a lot of little ways in which they control how you’re able to teach that amount to little more than petty micromanagement (can’t pause recording for a Zoom class session, no virtual background control for same). But the very frustrating part is when you ask for curriculum to teach a class they don’t have something developed to hand you. There’s a broad program curriculum but individual classes don’t have materials or explicit learning goals. This is fine when I’m on contract and that’s part of the job but this is an hourly instructor job. Curriculum development isn’t part of that unless they’re going to pay me for it. I end up doing a lot of free labor to be able to teach the classes.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Work with good people and the like
cons: Many of the students don’t care

review_title: The place has so much potential
job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The students and faculty are among the pros. The school has the potential to be a great, competitive university. Students from all over the world, talented, diverse instructors, dedicated staff. Generally, a nice place to work.
cons: Lack of recognition for faculty and staff. Department heads are great, but the upper upper management - or whoever it is who decides to ignore performance reviews from department heads and students year in and year out and not give at least the occasional pay increases for good performance is a big con and drain on morale.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Burbank, CA
pros: The people are good and the culture is friendly.
cons: The compensation package is really lacking.

review_title: Scapegoating employees to disillusion themselves from responsibility.
job_title: Professor in South Beach, FL
pros: The location of the school is nice.
cons: The administrative staff has a culture of finding scapegoats to blame so they don't have to take responsibility for their own shortcomings. They like to smile at you and then find ways to manipulate the truth in their own favor.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Burbank, CA
pros: Very fun atmosphere, casual dress, enjoyable work daily!
cons: Part time hours in some positions without benefits

job_title: Media Content in Burbank, CA
pros: Centrally located in Burbank. You get to visit and work on the WB and Universal backlots. Lots of networking opportunities with other employees, who come from all over the world. Everybody is always working on something, so it's easy to pad out your reel. Benefits are pretty decent for full time employees.
cons: The administration is stingy. Raises are basically non-existent. Upward mobility is extremely difficult due to favoritism. Decisions that have company-wide effects are based on petty rivalries between departments, whether or not they negatively impact employees and students. Departments actively work against each other to the detriment of everybody involved. It literally feels like high school, except with 40-60 year old "professionals" just constantly bickering.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Location of the schools is the only good thing about that place
cons: It's all about the money, nothing more

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The instructors are very cool and the location of the LA campus is nice.
cons: Upper management has absolutely no idea what they’re doing. They value profit over education. The HR department is full of mean girls. There is no internal support whatsoever and the pay is laughable. Do not work here.

review_title: Its so bad here... I don't think they will last
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The only good thing that came out of NYFA is the friendships.
cons: I can go on for days on how TOXIC everything about this establishment is, but I won't even waste my time trying to convince anyone about how terrible it is. Sometimes, you gotta just see it for yourself. Or better yet, watch the entire establishment crumble into pieces and file for bankruptcy.

review_title: Best first full-time job to have
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Burbank, CA
pros: Very friendly and caring staff! Located off the highway, so easily accessible.
cons: No room for growth. Not many perks or good benefits. Some incompetence.

review_title: So you accepted a job with New York Film Academy?
job_title: Administration in New York, NY
pros: Read below, it should be entertaining at the very least.
cons:
What to know about NYFA

NYFA offers visual and performing arts, the filmmaking and acting for film being their bread and butter. The most popular programs are called 1-year Conservatories, they are usually between 9 and 11 months. Some campuses offer some of the disciplines as 3-year degree programs where you would graduate with a bachelor of fine arts. The degrees have only recently obtained the legitimacy of regional accreditation, although very few people, and absolutely zero students understand what one type of accreditation means relative to another. 

 Courses like Game Design and Illustration either do not run at all, or only run when a few kids are naive enough to sign up without asking too many questions. The school is dominated by international students from wealthy backgrounds, or state-funded education. When a domestic student comes to NYFA, either they too are from money, or in the sadder situation, make the unfortunate choice to attend a ~50k a year program (often mortgaging the entire cost + living expenses) for a skillset that provides almost zero chance for gainful employment.

Programs like Acting and Filmmaking ARE intensive and challenging and contain lots of information. However, in my 7 years of time at the school studying the curriculum and layouts for all programs, I notice that the programs are packed more so because of regulations and want of a quick turn around than because it would provide an enhanced learning experience to the student.

 The school sells its programs as "accelerated" (read: money mill), which essentially means the course load is so immense and the time between semesters so small that most students slime through the projects and whatever skills they learn stick for only so long as they’re in the program, and then are dumped out, ~$50k poorer with a very weak remunerative skillset.


What to know about the internal operations of NYFA


The school's founder was a somewhat eccentric millionaire that had a penchant for subservient asian women and maintained a troupe of them until his passing. One could find him seated in his office, overlooking Battery Park or Union Square, beard and hair being trimmed with scissors, feet massaged, being served espresso by his harem of Asian women ostensibly imported with him from his time abroad prior to creating the film school. 

Other than that, my reflection is that the man was indeed a genius. He realized he can sell expensive tuition to people who loved acting and filmmaking but possessed zero talent for it. He realized that the words "New York'' in front of anything give it a veneer of respectability and credence in the eyes of the international community. He realized even further that Americans will grow to respect a domestic business or organization if the international impression is favorable even if none is justified. He paid well for talented young people to bring energy, sexiness and enthusiasm to his business. He also knew he was selling sexiness--the campus locations were originally New York, then Los Angeles, and finally Miami. While you can make an argument that NY/LA are media/entertainment/film destinations, Miami leaves you scratching your head. The point is that bored rich kids from abroad are not coming to study in Sandusky, Ohio and he knew that. They want to come to New York and LA and see the illusion of the United States. NYFA is all about illusion and its puts on a great presentation.

Many have commented in the other reviews that there is a disparity in pay between people working at the school. I believe the old man was much more liberal in how much he paid his employees because he had an extremely high bar for output, efficiency, and work ethic. He also expected that everyone would be bringing money into the school by selling the programs. Those that were not actively selling programs to people quite clearly get paid less. 
With his passing, that close-to-the-heart business ethic went out the window for the sterile divided labor approach of a much larger corporation that pays bare bones and cares little about rewarding and retaining high performers, instead insisting on uniformity and compliance to menial details. This resulted in NYFA bleeding its most talented and respectable employees and replacing them with aloof and incompetent ones desperate for even a meager paycheck.


The founder's death somewhere in 2016-2018 left the door open for his son to grab the reins of the family business. As is usually the case when a business is inherited, and as other reviewers have noted, the new principle brought little to enhance the business and had many idiosyncrasies, ideas, and behaviors that many found annoying, counterproductive, and generally off putting. Almost every interaction I witnessed him being a part of was muddied up by his awkward demeanor. He lacked the charm, wit and insight of his father, but maintained his arrogant and condescending attitude all the same.


Running the day to day operations of the school is a motley crew of ivy-league know-it-alls that take turns talking themselves in circles on all types of issues. They fancy themselves as artists more than administrators of a college and as such you will find the president of the school playing director of a silly commercial that plays like a bad daytime television advertisement, or the vice president pirouetting down the hallways talking to anyone who will listen to him about his workout routine or how much he spent on his most recent turtleneck purchase. Many years of complete comedy are in store for you if you do decide to take the job!

Underneath the president and senior vice president of the school is a cabal of vice presidents that range from a long-in-the-tooth used car salesman with a fake smile and an overt interest in what the younger female employees did over the weekend and an australian woman who finds not only a way to implement a completely self-destructive internal software system as her first act as a VP, but also ways to make the receptionists’ life hell--way to take on more responsibility! You would be hard pressed to find anyone at the company who can tell you exactly what these two people are responsible for, and even harder pressed to find an answer that justifies their purported salary, but there are hundreds of unsolvable mysteries at that school, so why act surprised?

The faculty is NYFA's most attractive quality, but not without flaws, in some cases, major ones. Each department has a head faculty member, some have been resting on their laurels for decades, some are still active participants in their given field/discipline. Some are well-rounded educators, some are simply a name to give the department a boost with zero teaching ability.
Many of the faculty are dedicated, hardworking professionals. I can't think of one that wasn't to be honest. They work hard to train unappreciative, petulant, and entitled rich kids (that is really the only type of student who can afford NYFA) and more than likely will never receive anything close to a tenured position or full-time status at the least. Some have very little classroom training and spend the majority of the day crudely providing instructions on a technical filmmaking technique, others lack the ability to manage the interpersonal interactions requisite between instructor and student.
 Despite the shortcomings, the biggest disadvantage the faculty faces is their complete lack of organization and leadership. This trickles down in a myriad of ways and is much more pronounced in the small programs that get less love and money, leaving students in those programs a much different impression of the school.

Moving on to the school’s philosophy and moral compass: NYFA and its faculty are fiercely, unapologetically, to the point of lacking any self-reflection, far left. You may be surprised how much politics comes up in discussions if you choose to work there--especially since everyone has an arts background, never worked a job outside of film/tv, and almost nobody has any education in STEM, political science, Econ or Business or Law--many, especially the most senior, seem very quick to wax philosophical about their views and to disagree with them is to brand yourself as a monster incapable of critical thinking or compassion. You probably shouldn't even consider working in the Arts or higher education if you find yourself a moderate or conservative, let alone working in NY, LA, or Miami at a film school. 

After the head leadership and the faculty is what we can call Administration. At NYFA, there are essentially 3 components of Administration, there are other little side jobs like the Dean of Students office and the Equipment room people, but who really cares about them?:

 1. Recruitment or Sales--these are the people on the phones, they call themselves admission representatives, not counselors, because they are really not qualified to counsel anyone on anything. Like the other departments, people come and go often, mostly because making calls to people in Nigeria to solicit them to pay 50k+ to journey to an expensive foreign country to learn acting is a fool’s errand, but where there is a will there's a way. Almost entirely men and white. It must be the evil nature in their hearts that draws them to such a reprehensible line of work. 

Supporting the “callers” are a few "recruiters'' that are paid to find stray international students from a basket of countries. They are the principle drivers of business for NYFA--as domestic students are generally not foolish enough to swallow the ~$50k a year price tag when many other options exist in their home state. NYFA has an outrageous Chinese student population at the LA campus and before the disastrous economic conditions hit, South African, Saudi Arabian, and Brazilian students dominated the other school in NY. The recruiters also look to India and Nigeria for students and they are successful. Even in these countries, with especially large levels of poverty, NYFA manages to seduce the wealthiest kids to come study for a year or two in the sexy destinations of NY or LA. The recruiters and sales people are probably the highest paid group in NYFA outside of senior officers and high level faculty. I see many comments talking about sexism and pay disparities, but as far as I know, most of the recruiters were female and they were usually paid more than their male counterparts, not because of sexism, but because their recruitment efforts yielded more business for the school--a meritocratic remnant of the deceased founder’s philosophy.

2. Bursar, Financial Aid, and Registrar--these people are responsible for all the day-to-day state and federal requirements involving different higher education laws and regulations. They make sure the paperwork is up to date and do the more generalized tasks that require little to no customer (student) interaction. The Registrar, usually an important role at any major college, is usually replaced every 3-6 months in the 7 years I was an employee. The most underpaid people working at the school were undoubtedly the people who worked in the registrar and bursar offices doing the basic paperwork--many give up the job in favor of something else within a few weeks or months at most.

3. Media, Advertisement, etc: NYFA's image is its best feature. As mentioned before, you can place the words ``New York" in front of anything and people will light up if you tell them you went there. Try it! Say to someone, “I went to New York Steak House last night for dinner, best steaks ever!”, or, “I learned how to pilot a hot air balloon at the New York Institute for Air Balloonery”, and people will not only accept it without question, but nod fiercely in approval about what a respected establishment it is. With their work half-done for them, the people working in NYFA’s Marketing department are generally low-paid and skilled glad-hands who plaster the brand NYFA over every document, social media post, and stupid blog article they can in a day’s worth of work. They use old videos of interviews with movie stars and directors voraciously intent on bleeding out every ounce of credibility one can muster from the association of the school’s name with any Bollywood/Hollywood/Nollywood project or star.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Burbank, CA
pros: Great co-workers and awesome location to work! You are surrounded by creative people in all departments. Even admin positions are filled with filmmakers, actors, writers, etc.
cons: Pay is low. Opportunities for advancement are limited. At one time management was there to listen. However, as the company grew, it became more corporate. The HR department is horrendous and the climate and "culture" has become toxic.

review_title: The most toxic workplace I've ever had the misfortune of working at
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
There are a handful of people who try their best to make things right for students, but the lack of management, vision and leadership makes it impossible for anything to get done.

They also often hire people without having any idea what the job will really be, so if you're good at talking and and making stuff up as you go, then you'll probably wow them (at first.) But when you actually start working there, you'll realize nobody knows what they're doing or what's happening most of the time.
cons:
This place functions less like a school and more like a fire department -- they put out fires as they happen. Better yet, it's a lot like working for the Trump administration. Huge turnover and incompetence, with figureheads blaming things on their underlings, while they screw around, scream and micro-manage. They might say they love you when they hire you, but pretty soon, if you have half a brain, they'll dump five different jobs on you (that you weren't trained or hired for.) If you manage to do all that and ask for a raise, HR (the worst I've ever experienced) will give you a million reasons why you can't get one. The people who last here are the ones who either do five jobs for the price of one (and keep their mouths shut) or the people who do nothing, but are great at shouting and complaining. 

You might look at a few of their employees who've been there for a LONG time and think -- wow, they must really like working here. But trust me, they're as miserable as you are (or will be.) A lot of the admin folks are Chapman, USC, NYU grads whose film careers never took off, so they settled here for that steady paycheck. They've convinced themselves that this is a normal workplace (that it's "worse" elsewhere) but trust me -- it's not. It's not normal to not know what your job is going in, then to muddle your way through, being treated like scum. It's not normal to be at the mercy of middle-aged men who are fighting because of their fragile egos, and who use you as their pawns. Unless you are one of them, you are better off working anywhere else.

job_title: Technical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: if you work in post or the equipment room, you get hours
cons: upper management is a mess. No benefits

job_title: Technical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Its flexible schedule I guess, but it's part-time so you don't get paid much.
cons: Most of the upper management people suck and will not respect you unless you are there for maybe 6 years.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Burbank, CA
pros: Eager students and supportive immediate supervisor
cons: Not a lot of prep pay

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Opportunities for advancement and travel, knowledgeable staff, supportive HR and counselor, nice facilities
cons: Sometimes there is poor communication about curriculum

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great team of people to work for!
cons: Very low pay. Benefits are terrible.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: They provided a lot of flexibility in the beginning and seemed to really appreciate artistic background. It was great environment to learn about education, and public speaking. Decent benefits and 401K
cons:
Flexibility changed and everything was micro managed but under very bad management. At one point the owner of the school would sit behind us to watch our screens without saying a word and would burst out. On another occasion, they made us send all of our emails to our direct manager for pre approval. This put us behind with weeks of work. They wanted at least two reps there for the day after thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years.
We had so many mixed messages. At one point they wanted us to take people on 3+ hour tours but then were upset we didn't make that many calls that day. 
They never wanted to pay for things that matter like marketing or travel. We were always at college fairs with outdated materials.
We were asked to push for programs that they didn't have a curriculum or a teacher for. 
When managers would leave, they blamed the managers and Upper management never took responsibility. Upper management, never asked us how they can help the team and what tools we needed. Upper management is not diverse, all white men who have been in the company for yrs who are dismissive to input. It's unfortunate since the entire school is so diverse.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Cambridge, MA
pros: Intelligent and creatively driven team
cons: It was a long commute from my residence

job_title: Receptionist in Burbank, CA
pros: The owners are not watching what you are doing most of your day. There are not enough supervisors to monitor you. You can browse the internet, social media websites, and be on your phone throughout the day. Great company to work for if you are fresh out of college, don't have much work experience, and work for almost minimum wage pay. You can get hired easily if you know someone working for the company. Your co-workers are in the early to late 20's, young work place.
cons: The Directors are always yelling and uptight with people when they are having a bad day. You work long hours and do not get paid overtime. If you ask for overtime they yell at you for working overtime after they give you a 3 person job. No credit or appreciation is given from any of the managers. Your co-workers start so much drama and conflict. Would be best to never share anything to anyone or else your personal life will be shared to everyone, even to the owner.  The employees are not very driven or motivated.  The company offers no room for growth for a REAL career. These jobs are only for those who do not know exactly what they want to do with their lives and just want to make the minimum of the average salary offered at other well established companies.

review_title: Multicultural classes make for challenging teaching; poor administration squanders potential
job_title: in Los Angeles, CA
pros: What's best: the satisfaction of teaching interested, nimble students with fewer academic boundaries.  The company seems to be growing, so there's probably the potential to move up (whatever that means?!?)  NYFA is more of a trade school than a college environment, which in many ways is appropriate for teaching the craft of filmmaking.
cons: Coordination between programs and majors is terrible.  Filmmaking is a collaborative venture but NYFA does a poor job of bringing the various student skills and interests together to create a more complete "real world" experience.  No viable intern program for near-graduates.  A sense that you're teaching alone and a disconnection to others' efforts.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The school is clearly trying to make progressive changes to their overall work culture and environment. They are gradually introducing more benefits and a more caring attitude towards employees and students. They offer a really wonderful program and the Faculty and Staff across all departments are wonderful and dedicated to their work.
cons: NYFA is very disorganized for such a huge, and well established institution.  Operations need to be overhauled and streamlined and some fundamental attitudes need to change.  Senior management is highly reactionary, which often opts for quick fixes rather than sustainable, long-term solutions.

job_title: Admissions in Burbank, CA
pros: Coworkers often have fun banter and make work lively and interesting. Often supportive of each other’s art. Open Houses are fun because we stay productive and the work feels useful.
cons:
The executives are awkward and watch you like hawks, the admissions manager is shrill and intense, the air conditioning is constantly swaying from too hot to way too cold, coworkers often fight over trivial things. On most days the work feels like it has no point. 
The management makes it very clear in how they speak about students that money is their biggest focus, by a wide margin.
The quality of the sample work in orientation videos ranges wildly, sometimes looking decent. Most times though, it’s embarrassing to represent a school like this, especially considering how much students pay to go here.

review_title: Needs to be run as a school, not as a business.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Most of the staff and teachers I worked with were great. 
- Flexible schedule. Good work/life balance.
cons:
- NYFA is being run as a for-profit money machine. The most important thing is how much money goes into the owner's pocket. 
- Employees do not get any kind of support from upper management. 
- Salary was adequate but there were no benefits. 
- Facilities (classrooms, offices, restrooms, lounges) are maintained as cheaply as possible and are often disgusting.

review_title: If you are able to work like a machine without your brain, go for it.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Flexible hour, friendly co-worker,  great location
cons:
Bursar office is the hell hole in this company.  Tons of works are waiting for you every day, and they don't want to hire more people to do the job. Nobody will appreciate how much work you have done but will complain when you make a mistake.  No career, no promotion, no appreciation at all in this office.  Extremely uncomfortable working environment. The room for bursar office is pretty small compares to the rooms for admission counselor and marketing department. I still believe this is racial discrimination since all the employees working in bursar office are Asian and black, but those who are working in admission office and marketing are white. 
STAY AWAY FROM THE BURSAR OFFICE.
STAY AWAY FROM THE COMPANY IF YOU ARE NOT WHITE.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Great Co-Workers
Work near a beautiful view of the river.
SWAG.
Creative artsy environment.
Student shows and movie tickets
cons:
No bonus or raise considerations.
You have one title but your workload has 10 others. 
If you're not senior management or someone whose been there for a long time, consider yourself invisible. 
Diversity where? 
Communication is awful.

review_title: Office Assistant At New York Film Academy
job_title: Office Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great staff communication. Everyone on the staff was very helpful during my first days with the company. I loved the fact that we got work with Mac Computers.
cons: I thought that upper management of the company was very arrogant and never seemed to do any work. I thought that there was an overall lack of customer service at the company.

job_title: Part Time Teacher's Assistant in New York, NY
pros:
-Multicultural atmosphere
-Access to film equipment
-Flexible hours if part time
-Teachers and coworkers are usually friendly and nice to work with,
cons:
-Zero communication between departments
-While the lower ranked employees are friendly, the administration is not and care more about making money than any of their students.  They view the students as products on an assembly line.
-Unreliable work schedule if part-time
-Deeply, deeply unorganized

review_title: Low-stress, film-related work to keep you busy and paid between jobs.
job_title: Teacher Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The pros to being a TA at NYFA: access to the academy's resources (for use in your own projects), very flexible schedule (it's made every week around Friday), and creative atmosphere (more from the students than the staff).
cons: The cons to being a TA at NYFA: not enough hours and there are some crazy and malicious people among the managers and upper management.

job_title: Agent in New York, NY
pros: Entry level pay is higher than many companies.
cons: Many employees working there, including myself, receive verbal abuse from management. The school is very expensive and there is an atmosphere of  us pushing sales rather than trying to make it worth the cost to attend. I became aware of several tactics used to mislead prospective students, employees, and the state about the school. For example, the school is required to have a library of related material for students. Well, when it came time for a state visit the school sets up a library so as not to be in violation, and then breaks it down when the state leaves. People are very unhappy working here.

review_title: Great as your first part-time job.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Burbank, CA
pros:
Students are great.  You really learn a lot about their culture.
Some co-workers can be great to talk and collaborate on projects with.
cons: Upper management sees you as a ghost. They believe everything is done magically and expect it to be that way every single day.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Creative people, inspirational instructors and a lot of brilliant people. Autonomy and the fact that this is a well-oiled machine that is still growing and offers a lot of opportunity. They're moving in the right direction - have hired an HR Team and working to get 20 years of backlog up to date.
cons: Slow moving, lack of growth, and no recognition. Low pay.

job_title: Teaching Assistant/Producer in New York, NY
pros:
Great Co-workers 
Flexible Hours 
Variety of projects 
Diversity of student body 
Campuses around the world 
Working in the classroom can be lots of fun
cons:
Lack of Moral 
Possibility of stagnation
Unreliable work schedule 
Miscommunication 
Small Budgets 
Cheap President 
Small paycheck 
Miscommunications between various departments

job_title: Instructor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good program for a trade school, knowledgeable teachers who care about subject matter
cons: Main building is feeling its age (air conditioning system for example) and other classes are spread throughout the city, parking situation is frustrating, low student population in some departments, the school has very few resources for instructors, the job requires long hours preparing and grading material without compensation. No culture for faculty.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
You're not a volunteer?  The only pro I can think of is that you get paid.

The best part is that the company is so unorganized that some people continue to come to the office to pick up their checks months after quitting.
cons: Abhorrent, repugnant, despicable workplace.  Sexual, emotional, and physical harassment is not only tolerated, but encouraged.  Leaders suggest that employees provide sexual favors to help bring more money to the company and support the founder's use of vulgar and abusive language toward employees; as there's no HR department, there's no accountability.

review_title: den of dishonesty, bad management, owners that gouge students, and a financial aid nightmare for domestic students
job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: the staff really does try, despite managements undermining them at every turn. If they want to keep you they will pay you just enough above market to insure that if you leave you wont see that money again, but then they act like they own you. The 3D Animation and Game design depts do seem to be very up to date.
cons: Where does one begin,  Management and specifically the owners and the management at the LA campus Jean Sherlock and his minions, the NY campus management is a bit less odious  and dishonest, are only really interested in money, they have tried this past year to change the school so it's more education centered, but since that has lead to a decline in revenue growth they are grinding employees into the ground. The amount of financial aid available as actual grants is so small that students that need residence are looking at 100K to 200K in student loans to attend. Due to this the student body is probably 70% intl. and 15% Veterans. The Intl. students all have language issues so your american acting student is learning the craft of acting with people who don't speak English well, from what I noticed  many of the veterans that attend are emotionally unbalanced and has lead to some awkward incidents on both campuses, and most of the domestic students that do attend  are such a mess, they could not get into any other performing arts college. Many of the students are very wealthy so they just miss classes which screws it it for students that have to work with them on projects. So the attrition rate is horrendous and students leave all the time, thus the tread mill of a very aggressive telemarketing and outside admissions (really sales ) dept. of 50 or 60 people to bring in students. All in all, if you are looking at this and saying ok, I could survive this mess for a year or two for the higher pay, ok, but planning a career at NYFA is just an excercise in emotional turmoil and backstabbing politics.

review_title: You expect it to be better
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Lively, positive vibe, lots of talented people around. If in addition you want to learn some of film making, doors are open.
cons: Sometimes things get too personal, some people work a lot and are not enough appreciated, when others can neglect some of their very essential duties and it still will be fine.

review_title: Disorganized and underpaid is an understatement . Wish I could give no stars.
job_title: Summer Camp Counselor in Burbank, CA
pros: The kids at the summer camp are very sweet. They are the only real reason that the camp is worthwhile. You make a difference in these child's lives while spending three months with them being their counselor. You get to live in a hotel where expenses are paid for (you have a roommate they choose for you ; which is a nightmare system), they give you a meal stipend.
cons: The head of the department has been there for 8 years and you would think she just started yesterday. Disorganization and unprofessionalism is the only way they handle any type of situation. They don't treat their employees fairly and often times , forget they haven't given someone a day off and illegally try and work them/make up for it. Their biggest priority is to protect the identity of the camp; even if that means firing anyone and everyone regardless of the reason. They are money chasers none the less, hence why the turn over rate is so large. RARELY do any of the counselors come back. The pay is minimum wage with little overtime. They don't tell you everything upfront about the job in the interview because if they did, no one would work there. You aren't just a summer camp counselor, they put you into a category whether that be "driving everyday to lax, planning activities(with little to no budget even though people's tuition for camp is outrageous)" etc. These categories are very uncomfortable for most since they tend to hire out of state counselors because they have no choice but to stay the entire camp. They avoid anyone local because they can leave at the drop of a dime, which they often do within the first week. Large lack of leadership and explanation to complete the tasks at hand because no one knows what they are doing.

review_title: I mean, it's a for-profit school
job_title: Support in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The students are great. They have big dreams, and they are willing to put in the work. I also really loved my immediate coworkers.
cons: Mind-numbing bureaucracy. The hoops you have to jump through for something simple are insane. It's run less like a school and more like a business.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Burbank, CA
pros: Flexibility of schedule. You are able to do more outside work if something comes up.
cons: Lack of communication in all facets of the school. Each department lacks the basic knowledge to communicate with one another.

review_title: Good for a short period of time

job_title: IT Director in Burbank, CA
